block.p: LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-27
LEAD: INTERNATIONAL/3-27
INTERNATIONAL/3-27
A tide of East Germans continued to flow over West Berlin and West Germany by foot car and train. More important for East Germany, most people were returning. Page 1

One family visiting West Berlin said they were more or less satisfied with East Germany. ''What bothered us most was that they always treated us like idiots,'' the mother said. ''That is really changed now.'' 1
East German emigres meditate on their decision 19
In East Berlin, everyone is away for the holiday 19
Bonn seeks to allay fears of Poland and Hungary 21
Soviet officials are applauding the crowds pouring through the newly perforated Iron Curtain. 1
Regular Soviet citizens see an omen of their own progress 22
Exchange with Gorbachev leaves Bush hopeful
Crackdown in Moldavia 17
Bulgarians remain skeptical 23
The Abu Nidal terrorist ring is divided by a murderous internal power struggle in which more than 150 members of the group have reportedly been killed. 1
Iran and terror seen still linked 15
Arab groups fear Israeli curbs on donations 27
Egypt's President outlines economic changes 16

Iranian-style veils in Paris schools? A hot political issue was set off in France when the Government told three militant Muslim girls they could not attend school with the veils. 5 Parisian traffic: out of hand or out of sight? 6
Spanish Socialists lose majority 4
The Thai leader has canceled visits to the U.S., Japan and Denmark to deal with the aftermath of a typhoon that has left nearly 400 people dead. 9
The youth vote is a sleeping giant of Indian politics 10
Peru's rebels are threatening to kill people who vote in nationwide municipal elections on Sunday. 3
Salvador rebels mount attacks across the capital 11
A sour anniversary for Brazil's monarchists 13
Two archbishops symbolize conflict in the Brazilian church 14
The clients of Kissinger Associates cannot be disclosed, officials say. Deputy Secretary Lawrence Eagleburger promised disclosure before his Senate confirmation. 8
Namibia turnout over 90% 3
Japanese charitable giving is up in U.S.
NATIONAL/28-37
Aliens with false amnesty claims will begin getting permanent resident status next month. Officials say they will not be able to find most fraud. 1
Do cities or states fight drugs? Even as mayors and governors are fighting over which ought to control new Federal money to combat drugs. 1
A path of environmental destruction left by Hurricane Hugo is just now being catalogued. It will take years for some areas to recover.
South Carolina loss: $3.7 billion 32
Bay Area life after the earthquake is vastly different, with many annoyances becoming unsettling to San Franciscans and Oaklanders. 28
Washington arrested 212 people at an abortion clinic, setting an uneasy tone as thousands arrived for an abortion rights rally today. 33
The possibility of recent budget cuts staying in effect for the entire fiscal year is causing consternation in many Federal agencies. 34
Acid rain pact is reached 35
Lujan tries to counter drive against offshore oil wells 28
Chicago race relations remain tense, with Mayor Daley under fire for not having enough blacks in top government jobs. Aides say many blacks refuse to work for Mr. Daley. 28
Gonorrhea outbreak among homosexuals concerns Seattle 30
New service created for parishes without priests 31
Miami officer's trial is stalled 28
Helga pictures sold
REGIONAL/39-48
Rules to reduce Medicaid fraud in New York State have been postponed indefinitely. They face an uncertain future after two legal setbacks. 40
David Dinkins wants cabinet choices to create trust and make a stamp of change while representing New York City's diverse communities. 2
City's campaign finance law is rated only a partial success 42
Must children attend AIDS classes? A New York court case involves 220 Long Island children religiously opposed to the required classes. 40
Student wants F.B.I. file purged
A freeze on phone rates is thawing a year early in New York State. Governor Cuomo and New York Telephone announced the freeze in 1987. 47
Officer stabbed to death 40
Customs faulted in cocaine case 48
Protests greet removal of top AIDS officials
Fernandez offers post to 'spy' superintendent
